prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Effect of Transfer: Proceedings in the Transferee Court

head.headtext: Management of transferred cases—Management of discovery

para.paratext: It is well recognized by most attorneys and judges that discovery plays an especially important role in complex litigation. It is also commonly under stood that the need for judicial intervention and management of discovery increases as the complexity of the litigation increases. Accordingly, the management of discovery is an important part of the activities of a transferee judge presiding over cases transferred by the Panel for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.

The statute creating the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation recognizes the important role discovery plays in the pretrial proceedings and it specifically authorizes the transferee judge (and others) to preside over discovery. Section (b) of the statute provides in part:

The judge or judges to whom such actions are assigned, the members of the judicial panel on multidistrict litigation, and other circuit and district judges designated when needed by the panel may exercise the powers of a district judge in any district for the purpose of conducting pretrial depositions in such coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.[1]
This power has been relied on by the Panel in ordering transfer.[2]

Much of the Manual for Complex Litigation is devoted to management of discovery,[3] and the Panel has recognized the role of the Manual in multidistrict litigation.[4] The Panel has, for example, cited the Manual[5] in support of transfer because the Manual permits the transferee court to allow previously taken discovery to be used by all parties.[6] The Panel has also recognized the potential use of a document depository as a means of facilitating efficiency if transfer is ordered for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.[7]

One important facet of the Panel's view of discovery in transferred cases arises with respect to requests by parties that their cases not be transferred because of the unique factual issues presented by those cases. The Panel has generally not been receptive to these arguments.[8] The Panel has frequently stated, however, that the transferee court is free to enter appropriate management orders to permit the common discovery to proceed and also provide for the individual needs of the several litigants.[9] The Panel has expressly recognized that the transferee court can establish separate discovery and motion tracks to deal with separate issues.[10] The Manual for Complex Litigation allows a trial court to excuse parties from discovery in which they have no interest,[11] and the Panel has specifically recognized that the transferee court can use this power.[12] The Panel has stated:

Any antagonistic interests among the parties in the various actions may be accommodated by the transferee judge in designing the pretrial program. And discovery on any issues unique to [a single action] may be scheduled by the transferee judge to proceed in a separate discovery schedule concurrently with discovery on common issues.[13]

Parties occasionally urge the Panel to limit the scope of discovery upon transfer. The Panel has regularly declined these requests.[14] With respect to a request that it limit the scope of discovery on non-common issues, the Panel in one case stated:

These requests are misdirected, for the Panel has neither the power nor the inclination to dictate in any way the manner in which the coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings are to be conducted by the transferee judge. The scope of those proceedings, including the extent to which discovery is permitted, is a matter exclusively within the control of the transferee judge.[15]

The Panel has also deferred to the transferee court to determine the extent to which consolidation and coordination should be ordered between the actions transferred by the Panel and the actions already pending in the transferee court.[16]
The transferee court may order bifurcation of litigation, and may defer discovery on some issues until after the trial of a threshold issue.[17]

The Panel has also specifically recognized the power of the transferee court to manage the entire litigation in order to avoid delay in the proceedings.[18] Although control of discovery is a central part of pretrial management, the transferee court may properly control all facets of the pretrial proceedings. The transferee court can enter orders during pretrial proceedings that affect and limit how the cases will be tried upon remand.[19]

The plenary power of the transferee courts—perhaps powerful beyond any express grant of authority—is seen in the area of discovery. The federal rules of civil procedure fairly clearly contemplate that motions relating to non-party discovery pursuant to subpoenas be decided by the court issuing the subpoena.[20] Notwithstanding that direction, transferee courts have held that they would hear motions relating to depostions, typically relying on the broad scope of § 1407.[21] These cases essentially stand for a view of plenary power of the transferee court. Where an issue arises relating to the commanded production of documents without a scheduled deposition, the “normal” command of the rules is just as strong, but the language of § 1407 is not as clear. Transferee courts in this situation have also tended to find plenary power in the transferee courts despite the absence of rule or statutory language supporting the result.[22] At least one court has reached the opposite conclusion, relying on the ability of Congress to expressly provide for this authority had it meant to do so.[23]

Another discovery device with special value in complex litigation is the so-called Lone Pine order. This order would require the plaintiffs to provide factual support in toxic tort and similar cases of exposure to the alleged damage-causing agent, or run the risk of having their claims dismissed.[24] At least one appellate court has held that a district court should not enter a Lone Pine order before determining that the claims would survive a motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim.[25]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
28 U.S.C.A. § 1407(b). The statute is set forth in § 3:19.
See, e.g., In re IBM Peripheral EDP Devices Antitrust Litigation, 411 F. Supp. 791, 792 (J.P.M.L. 1976).

For a more detailed discussion of the Manual and its role in discovery issues arising in complex and multidistrict litigation, see Roger S. Haydock & David F. Herr, Discovery Practice ch. 34 (8th ed. 2016).
See In re Delta Airlines Crash at Boston, Massachusetts, on July 31, 1973, 395 F. Supp. 1405, 1407 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
See Manual for Complex Litigation, parts I & 11, § 3.11 (rev. ed. 1973). Panel decisions relying on this Manual provision are collected in notes 11 and 12, above.
See, e.g., In re Motion Picture Licensing Antitrust Litigation, 479 F. Supp. 581, 582 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
See, e.g., In re Bestline Products Securities and Antitrust Litigation, 405 F. Supp. 313, 314 (J.P.M.L. 1975); In re Midwest Milk Monopolization Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 676, 678 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
The Panel's treatment of differing issues and progress of cases on initial transfer is discussed in § 5:45.

See, e.g., In re Deep Vein Thrombosis Litigation, 323 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re Cenco Inc. Securities Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 1237, 1239 (J.P.M.L. 1977); In re Republic National-Realty Equities Securities Litigation, 382 F. Supp. 1403, 1405-1406 (J.P.M.L. 1974); In re IBM Peripheral EDP Devices Antitrust Litigation, 375 F. Supp. 1376, 1377 (J.P.M.L. 1974); In re Air Crash Disaster at Duarte, Cal. on June 6, 1971, 346 F. Supp. 529, 530 (J.P.M.L. 1972).
In re Deep Vein Thrombosis Litigation, 323 F. Supp. 2d 1378, 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2004).

See Manual for Complex Litigation, pts. I and II, § 2.31 (rev. ed. 1977). Similar provisions are contained in Manual for Complex Litigation Fourth § 40.29 at 761 (2004) (pretrial deposition guideline order providing right to absent parties to conduct supplemental depositions).

See In re Investors Funding Corp. of New York Securities Litigation, 461 F. Supp. 673, 675 (J.P.M.L. 1978); In re Commonwealth Oil/Tesoro Petroleum Securities Litigation, 458 F. Supp. 225, 229–230 (J.P.M.L. 1978); In re “Fine Paper” Antitrust Litigation, 453 F. Supp. 118, 122 (J.P.M.L. 1978), aff'd, 685 F.2d 810 (3d Cir. 1982), cert. denied, 459 U.S. 1156, 103 S. Ct. 801, 74 L. Ed. 2d 1003 (1983); In re Airport Car Rental Antitrust Litigation, 448 F. Supp. 273, 275 (J.P.M.L. 1978); In re Fine Paper Antitrust Litigation, 446 F. Supp. 759, 760 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
In re Beef Industry Antitrust Litigation, 432 F. Supp. 211, 213 (J.P.M.L. 1977) (citations omitted); see also In re Corrugated Container Antitrust Litigation, 447 F. Supp. 468, 471 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
See, e.g., In re Sundstrand Data Control, Inc. Patent Litigation, 443 F. Supp. 1019, 1021–1022 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
See, e.g., In re Sundstrand Data Control, Inc. Patent Litigation, 443 F. Supp. 1019, 1021–1022 (J.P.M.L. 1978).

See In re America Online Spin-Off Accounts Litigation, 310 F. Supp. 2d 1369 (J.P.M.L. 2004) (transferee court can determine between coordination and consolidation); In re Aircraft Accident at Barrow, Alaska, on October 13, 1978, 474 F. Supp. 996, 999 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
See In re Data General Corp. Antitrust Litigation, 510 F. Supp. 1220, 1226 (J.P.M.L. 1979).
See In re Uranium Industry Antitrust Litigation, 458 F. Supp. 1223, 1231 (J.P.M.L. 1978).
See, e.g., In re Factor VIII or IX Concentrate Blood Products Litigation, 169 F.R.D. 632, 636 (N.D. Ill. 1996) (transferee court can enter order limiting number of expert witnesses at trial).

Fed. R. Civ. P. 37(a)(2) provides in part: “A motion for an order to a nonparty must be made in the court where the discovery is or will be taken.” See Wm. T. Thompson Co. v. General Nutrition Corp., Inc., 671 F.2d 100, 102 (3d Cir. 1982).

See, e.g., U.S. ex rel. Pogue v. Diabetes Treatment Centers of America, Inc., 444 F.3d 462, 468-69 (6th Cir. 2006) (noting that 28 U.S.C. § 1407(b) allows transferee judge to “exercise the powers of a district judge in any district for the purpose of conducting pretrial depositions”); In re Neurontin Marketing, Sales Practices, and Products Liability Litigation, 245 F.R.D. 55 (D. Mass. 2007); In re San Juan Dupont Plaza Hotel Fire Litigation, 117 F.R.D. 30, 32 (D.P.R. 1987).

See, e.g., In re Asbestos Products Liability Litigation (No. VI), 256 F.R.D. 151 (E.D. Pa. 2009); In re Neurontin Marketing, Sales Practices, and Products Liability Litigation, 245 F.R.D. 55 (D. Mass. 2007); In re Clients and Former Clients of Baron & Budd, P.C., 478 F.3d 670, 672 (5th Cir. 2007), cert. denied, 552 U.S. 812, 128 S. Ct. 354, 169 L. Ed. 2d 14 (2007).
See VISX, Inc. v. Nidek Co., 208 F.R.D. 615 (N.D. Cal. 2002).

See, e.g., In re Fosamax Products Liability Litigation, 2012 WL 5877418 (S.D.N.Y. 2012); In re Vioxx Products Liability Litigation, 557 F. Supp. 2d 741 (E.D. La. 2008). This device is named after Lore v. Lone Pine Corp., 1986 WL 637507, *1–*3 (N.J. Super. Ct. Law Div. 1986) (using a pre-trial order that required plaintiffs to provide some basic facts in the form of expert reports or run the risk of having their case dismissed).
Adinolfe v. United Technologies Corp., 768 F.3d 1161 (11th Cir. 2014).
